content.text: PHP Cookies
What is a Cookie?

A cookie is often used to identify a user. A cookie is a small file that the server embeds on the user's computer. Each time the same computer requests a page with a browser, it will send the cookie too. With PHP, you can both create and retrieve cookie values.
content.html: A cookie is often used to identify a user. A cookie is a small file that the server embeds on the user's computer. Each time the same computer requests a page with a browser, it will send the cookie too. With PHP, you can both create and retrieve cookie values.

content.text: Create Cookies With PHP
A cookie is created with the setcookie() function.
content.html: A cookie is created with the setcookie() function.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: setcookie(name, value, expire, path, domain, secure, httponly);

content.text: Only the name parameter is required. All other parameters are optional.
content.html: Only the name parameter is required. All other parameters are optional.

content.text: PHP Create/Retrieve a Cookie

The following example creates a cookie named "user" with the value "John Doe". The cookie will expire after 30 days (86400 * 30). The "/" means that the cookie is available in entire website (otherwise, select the directory you prefer).
content.html: The following example creates a cookie named "user" with the value "John Doe". The cookie will expire after 30 days (86400 * 30). The "/" means that the cookie is available in entire website (otherwise, select the directory you prefer).

content.text: We then retrieve the value of the cookie "user" (using the global variable $_COOKIE). We also use the isset() function to find out if the cookie is set:
content.html: We then retrieve the value of the cookie "user" (using the global variable $_COOKIE). We also use the isset() function to find out if the cookie is set:

syntaxHighlighting.text: ";  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.code: ";  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

syntax_highlighting.text: ";  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$cookie_name = "user";
$cookie_value = "John Doe";
setcookie($cookie_name, $cookie_value, time() + (86400 * 30), "/"); // 86400 = 1 day
?>
<html>
<body>

<?php
if(!isset($_COOKIE[$cookie_name])) {
  echo "Cookie named '" . $cookie_name . "' is not set!";
} else {
  echo "Cookie '" . $cookie_name . "' is set!<br>";
  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];
}
?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: ";  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.text: Note: The setcookie() function must appear BEFORE the <html> tag.
content.html: Note: The setcookie() function must appear BEFORE the <html> tag.

content.text: Note: The value of the cookie is automatically URLencoded when sending the cookie, and automatically decoded when received (to prevent URLencoding, use setrawcookie() instead).
content.html: Note: The value of the cookie is automatically URLencoded when sending the cookie, and automatically decoded when received (to prevent URLencoding, use setrawcookie() instead).

content.text: Modify a Cookie Value
To modify a cookie, just set (again) the cookie using the setcookie() function:
content.html: To modify a cookie, just set (again) the cookie using the setcookie() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: ";   echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.code: "; echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

syntax_highlighting.text: ";   echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$cookie_name = "user";
$cookie_value = "Alex Porter";
setcookie($cookie_name, $cookie_value, time() + (86400 * 30), "/");
?>
<html>
<body>

<?php
if(!isset($_COOKIE[$cookie_name])) {
  echo "Cookie named '" . $cookie_name . "' is not set!";
} else {
  echo "Cookie '" . $cookie_name . "' is set!<br>";
  echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];
}
?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: ";   echo "Value is: " . $_COOKIE[$cookie_name];}?>

content.text: Delete a Cookie
To delete a cookie, use the setcookie() function with an expiration date in the past:
content.html: To delete a cookie, use the setcookie() function with an expiration date in the past:

syntaxHighlighting.text: <?php// set the expiration date to one hour agosetcookie("user", "", time() - 3600);?>
// set the expiration date to one hour ago

content.code:
<?php// set the expiration date to one hour agosetcookie("user", "", time() - 3600);?>
<html>
<body>

<?phpecho "Cookie 'user' is deleted.";?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting.text: <?php// set the expiration date to one hour agosetcookie("user", "", time() - 3600);?>
// set the expiration date to one hour ago

content.code_html:
<?php
// set the expiration date to one hour ago
setcookie("user", "", time() - 3600);
?>
<html>
<body>

<?php
echo "Cookie 'user' is deleted.";
?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: <?php// set the expiration date to one hour agosetcookie("user", "", time() - 3600);?>
// set the expiration date to one hour ago

content.text: Check if Cookies are Enabled
The following example creates a small script that checks whether cookies are enabled. First, try to create a test cookie with the setcookie() function, then count the $_COOKIE array variable:
content.html: The following example creates a small script that checks whether cookies are enabled. First, try to create a test cookie with the setcookie() function, then count the $_COOKIE array variable:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpif(count($_COOKIE) > 0) {  echo "Cookies are enabled.";} else {
    echo "Cookies are disabled.";}
 ?>

content.code:
<?phpsetcookie("test_cookie", "test", time() + 3600, '/');?>
<html>
<body>

<?phpif(count($_COOKIE) > 0) {  echo "Cookies are enabled.";} else {
echo "Cookies are disabled.";}
?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpif(count($_COOKIE) > 0) {  echo "Cookies are enabled.";} else {
    echo "Cookies are disabled.";}
 ?>

content.code_html:
<?php
setcookie("test_cookie", "test", time() + 3600, '/');
?>
<html>
<body>

<?php
if(count($_COOKIE) > 0) {
  echo "Cookies are enabled.";
} else {
  echo "Cookies are disabled.";
}
?>

</body>
</html>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpif(count($_COOKIE) > 0) {  echo "Cookies are enabled.";} else {
    echo "Cookies are disabled.";}
 ?>
